explanation:
The MISRA Rule 21.17 concern is accesses beyond the bounds of objects passed to <string.h> functions and any code that writes into buffers derived from those pointers. The code uses memcpy in two places and performs indexed writes into body_dyn in two loops; these are the primary sites that can cause out-of-bounds accesses and therefore must be investigated. The malloc call that sets the buffer size is included because the allocated size (body_dyn_size) directly determines the valid range for subsequent string/memory operations.

Other fragments need not be investigated for this rule: the static const arrays (body_header, body_filler, body_footer) are compile-time constant objects with known sizes and are only read by the code; the MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ macro expands to a compile-time sizeof-based length and does not itself perform memory access; the NULL-check after malloc and the final free/cleanup logic do not use <string.h> functions and do not write into body_dyn. There are no other calls to <string.h> functions (e.g. strcpy/strncpy/strcat/strncat/memmove/memset/memcmp/strlen/strspn) in the shown function. Therefore the listed fragments are the relevant ones to inspect for potential out-of-bounds accesses under Rule 21.17.
